trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database - elastic database tools

trans-unit.source: Software as a Service (SaaS) developers can easily create elastic, scalable databases in the cloud using these tools
trans-unit.target: Software as a Service (SaaS) developers can easily create elastic, scalable databases in the cloud using these tools

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database features overview
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database features overview

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database features enables you to use the virtually unlimited database resources of Azure SQL Database to create solutions for transactional workloads, and especially Software as a Service (SaaS) applications.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database features enables you to use the virtually unlimited database resources of Azure SQL Database to create solutions for transactional workloads, and especially Software as a Service (SaaS) applications.

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database features are composed of the following:
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database features are composed of the following:

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database tools: These two tools simplify development and management of sharded database solutions.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database tools: These two tools simplify development and management of sharded database solutions.

trans-unit.source: The tools are: the <link><linkText>Elastic Database client library</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>Elastic Database split-merge tool</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The tools are: the <link><linkText>Elastic Database client library</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>Elastic Database split-merge tool</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Elastic Database pools</linkText><title></title></link> (preview): A pool is a collection of databases to which you can add or remove databases at any time.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Elastic Database pools</linkText><title></title></link> (preview): A pool is a collection of databases to which you can add or remove databases at any time.

trans-unit.source: The databases in the pool share a fixed amount of resources (known as database throughput units, or DTUs).
trans-unit.target: The databases in the pool share a fixed amount of resources (known as database throughput units, or DTUs).

trans-unit.source: You pay a fixed price for the resources, which enables you to easily calculate costs while managing performance.
trans-unit.target: You pay a fixed price for the resources, which enables you to easily calculate costs while managing performance.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Elastic Database jobs</linkText><title></title></link> (preview): Use jobs to manage large numbers of Azure SQL databases.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Elastic Database jobs</linkText><title></title></link> (preview): Use jobs to manage large numbers of Azure SQL databases.

trans-unit.source: Easily perform administrative operations such as schema changes, credentials management, reference data updates, performance data collection or tenant (customer) telemetry collection using jobs.
trans-unit.target: Easily perform administrative operations such as schema changes, credentials management, reference data updates, performance data collection or tenant (customer) telemetry collection using jobs.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Elastic Database query</linkText><title></title></link> (preview): Enables you to run a Transact-SQL query that spans multiple databases.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Elastic Database query</linkText><title></title></link> (preview): Enables you to run a Transact-SQL query that spans multiple databases.

trans-unit.source: This enables connection to reporting tools such as Excel, PowerBI, Tableau, etc.
trans-unit.target: This enables connection to reporting tools such as Excel, PowerBI, Tableau, etc.

trans-unit.source: Promises and challenges
trans-unit.target: Promises and challenges

trans-unit.source: Achieving elasticity and scale for cloud applications has been straightforward for compute and blob storage--simply add or subtract units.
trans-unit.target: Achieving elasticity and scale for cloud applications has been straightforward for compute and blob storage--simply add or subtract units.

trans-unit.source: But it has remained a challenge for stateful data processing in relational databases.
trans-unit.target: But it has remained a challenge for stateful data processing in relational databases.

trans-unit.source: We have seen these challenges emerge most prominently in the two following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: We have seen these challenges emerge most prominently in the two following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Growing and shrinking capacity for the relational database part of your workload.
trans-unit.target: Growing and shrinking capacity for the relational database part of your workload.

trans-unit.source: Managing hotspots that may arise affecting a specific subset of data – such as a particularly busy end-customer (tenant).
trans-unit.target: Managing hotspots that may arise affecting a specific subset of data – such as a particularly busy end-customer (tenant).

trans-unit.source: Traditionally, scenarios like these have been addressed by investing in larger-scale database servers to support the application.
trans-unit.target: Traditionally, scenarios like these have been addressed by investing in larger-scale database servers to support the application.

trans-unit.source: However, this option is limited in the cloud where all processing happens on predefined commodity hardware.
trans-unit.target: However, this option is limited in the cloud where all processing happens on predefined commodity hardware.

trans-unit.source: Instead, distributing data and processing across many identically-structured databases (a scale-out pattern known as "sharding") provides an alternative to traditional scale-up approaches both in terms of cost and elasticity.
trans-unit.target: Instead, distributing data and processing across many identically-structured databases (a scale-out pattern known as "sharding") provides an alternative to traditional scale-up approaches both in terms of cost and elasticity.

trans-unit.source: Horizontal and vertical scaling
trans-unit.target: Horizontal and vertical scaling

trans-unit.source: The figure below shows the horizontal and vertical dimensions of scaling, which are the basic ways the elastic databases can be scaled.
trans-unit.target: The figure below shows the horizontal and vertical dimensions of scaling, which are the basic ways the elastic databases can be scaled.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Horizontal versus Vertical Scaleout</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Horizontal versus Vertical Scaleout</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Horizontal scaling refers to adding or removing databases in order to adjust capacity or overall performance.
trans-unit.target: Horizontal scaling refers to adding or removing databases in order to adjust capacity or overall performance.

trans-unit.source: This is also called “scaling out”.
trans-unit.target: This is also called “scaling out”.

trans-unit.source: Sharding, in which data is partitioned across a collection of identically structured databases, is a common way to implement horizontal scaling.
trans-unit.target: Sharding, in which data is partitioned across a collection of identically structured databases, is a common way to implement horizontal scaling.

trans-unit.source: Vertical scaling refers to increasing or decreasing the performance level of an individual database—this is also known as “scaling up.”
trans-unit.target: Vertical scaling refers to increasing or decreasing the performance level of an individual database—this is also known as “scaling up.”

trans-unit.source: Most cloud-scale database applications will use a combination of these two strategies.
trans-unit.target: Most cloud-scale database applications will use a combination of these two strategies.

trans-unit.source: For example, a Software as a Service application may use horizontal scaling to provision new end-customers and vertical scaling to allow each end-customer’s database to grow or shrink resources as needed by the workload.
trans-unit.target: For example, a Software as a Service application may use horizontal scaling to provision new end-customers and vertical scaling to allow each end-customer’s database to grow or shrink resources as needed by the workload.

trans-unit.source: Horizontal scaling is managed using the <link><linkText>Elastic Database client library</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Horizontal scaling is managed using the <link><linkText>Elastic Database client library</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Vertical scaling is accomplished using Azure PowerShell cmdlets to change the service tier, or by placing databases in an Elastic Database pool.
trans-unit.target: Vertical scaling is accomplished using Azure PowerShell cmdlets to change the service tier, or by placing databases in an Elastic Database pool.

trans-unit.source: Single and multi-tenancy patterns
trans-unit.target: Single and multi-tenancy patterns

trans-unit.source: Sharding is a technique to distribute large amounts of identically-structured data across a number of independent databases.
trans-unit.target: Sharding is a technique to distribute large amounts of identically-structured data across a number of independent databases.

trans-unit.source: It is especially popular with cloud developers who are creating Software as a Service (SAAS) offerings for end customers or businesses.
trans-unit.target: It is especially popular with cloud developers who are creating Software as a Service (SAAS) offerings for end customers or businesses.

trans-unit.source: These end customers are often referred to as “tenants”.
trans-unit.target: These end customers are often referred to as “tenants”.

trans-unit.source: Sharding may be required for any number of reasons:
trans-unit.target: Sharding may be required for any number of reasons:

trans-unit.source: The total amount of data is too large to fit within the constraints of a single database
trans-unit.target: The total amount of data is too large to fit within the constraints of a single database

trans-unit.source: The transaction throughput of the overall workload exceeds the capabilities of a single database
trans-unit.target: The transaction throughput of the overall workload exceeds the capabilities of a single database

trans-unit.source: Tenants may require physical isolation from each other, so separate databases are needed for each tenant
trans-unit.target: Tenants may require physical isolation from each other, so separate databases are needed for each tenant

trans-unit.source: Different sections of a database may need to reside in different geographies for compliance, performance or geopolitical reasons.
trans-unit.target: Different sections of a database may need to reside in different geographies for compliance, performance or geopolitical reasons.

trans-unit.source: In other scenarios, such as ingestion of data from distributed devices, sharding can be used to fill a set of databases that are organized temporally.
trans-unit.target: In other scenarios, such as ingestion of data from distributed devices, sharding can be used to fill a set of databases that are organized temporally.

trans-unit.source: For example, a separate database can be dedicated to each day or week.
trans-unit.target: For example, a separate database can be dedicated to each day or week.

trans-unit.source: In that case, the sharding key can be an integer representing the date (present in all rows of the sharded tables) and queries retrieving information for a date range must be routed by the application to the subset of databases covering the range in question.
trans-unit.target: In that case, the sharding key can be an integer representing the date (present in all rows of the sharded tables) and queries retrieving information for a date range must be routed by the application to the subset of databases covering the range in question.

trans-unit.source: Sharding works best when every transaction in an application can be restricted to a single value of a sharding key.
trans-unit.target: Sharding works best when every transaction in an application can be restricted to a single value of a sharding key.

trans-unit.source: That ensures that all transactions will be local to a specific database.
trans-unit.target: That ensures that all transactions will be local to a specific database.

trans-unit.source: Some applications use the simplest approach of creating a separate database for each tenant.
trans-unit.target: Some applications use the simplest approach of creating a separate database for each tenant.

trans-unit.source: This is the single tenant sharding pattern that provides isolation, backup/restore ability and resource scaling at the granularity of the tenant.
trans-unit.target: This is the single tenant sharding pattern that provides isolation, backup/restore ability and resource scaling at the granularity of the tenant.

trans-unit.source: With single tenant sharding, each database is associated with a specific tenant ID value (or customer key value), but that key need not always be present in the data itself.
trans-unit.target: With single tenant sharding, each database is associated with a specific tenant ID value (or customer key value), but that key need not always be present in the data itself.

trans-unit.source: It is the application’s responsibility to route each request to the appropriate database – and the client library can simplify this.
trans-unit.target: It is the application’s responsibility to route each request to the appropriate database – and the client library can simplify this.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Single tenant versus multi-tenant</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Single tenant versus multi-tenant</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Others scenarios pack multiple tenants together into databases, rather than isolating them into separate databases.
trans-unit.target: Others scenarios pack multiple tenants together into databases, rather than isolating them into separate databases.

trans-unit.source: This is a typical multi-tenant sharding pattern – and it may be driven by the fact that an application manages large numbers of very small tenants.
trans-unit.target: This is a typical multi-tenant sharding pattern – and it may be driven by the fact that an application manages large numbers of very small tenants.

trans-unit.source: In multi-tenant sharding, the rows in the database tables are all designed to carry a key identifying the tenant ID or sharding key.
trans-unit.target: In multi-tenant sharding, the rows in the database tables are all designed to carry a key identifying the tenant ID or sharding key.

trans-unit.source: Again, the application tier is responsible for routing a tenant’s request to the appropriate database, and this can be supported by the elastic database client library.
trans-unit.target: Again, the application tier is responsible for routing a tenant’s request to the appropriate database, and this can be supported by the elastic database client library.

trans-unit.source: In addition, row-level security can be used to filter which rows each tenant can access – for details, see <link><linkText>Multi-tenant applications with elastic database tools and row-level security</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: In addition, row-level security can be used to filter which rows each tenant can access – for details, see <link><linkText>Multi-tenant applications with elastic database tools and row-level security</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Redistributing data among databases may be needed with the multi-tenant sharding pattern, and this is facilitated by the elastic database split-merge tool.
trans-unit.target: Redistributing data among databases may be needed with the multi-tenant sharding pattern, and this is facilitated by the elastic database split-merge tool.

trans-unit.source: Move data from multiple to single-tenancy databases
trans-unit.target: Move data from multiple to single-tenancy databases

trans-unit.source: When creating a SaaS application, it is typical to offer prospective customers a trial version of the software.
trans-unit.target: When creating a SaaS application, it is typical to offer prospective customers a trial version of the software.

trans-unit.source: In this case, it is cost-effective to use a multi-tenant database for the data.
trans-unit.target: In this case, it is cost-effective to use a multi-tenant database for the data.

trans-unit.source: However, when a prospect becomes a customer, a single-tenant database is better since it provides better performance.
trans-unit.target: However, when a prospect becomes a customer, a single-tenant database is better since it provides better performance.

trans-unit.source: If the customer had created data during the trial period, use the <link><linkText>split-merge tool</linkText><title></title></link> to move the data from the multi-tenant to the new single-tenant database.
trans-unit.target: If the customer had created data during the trial period, use the <link><linkText>split-merge tool</linkText><title></title></link> to move the data from the multi-tenant to the new single-tenant database.
